content: The "Teacher Education for Autistic Children Act of 2002" or the "TEACH Act of 2002" focuses on training special education teachers in autism spectrum disorders. The "TEACH Act of 2002" authorizes $15,000,000 annually from 2003 to 2007 for training teachers in autism spectrum disorders, developing standards, and providing technical assistance grants. The "TEACH Act of 2002" authorizes funding for training special education personnel, including teachers, aides, administrators, and specialists in autism spectrum disorders. The funds remain available until expended. Authorization of additional funding for competitive grants to improve results for children with autism spectrum disorders under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. $5,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007. Amounts remain available until expended. Additionally, a refundable tax credit is provided for education and training related to autism spectrum disorders. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new section on education and training for autism spectrum disorders. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified expenses related to education and training for autism spectrum disorders. The credit is limited to $10,000 per taxable year and covers tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and interest on qualified education loans. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a tax credit for expenses related to education and training for autism spectrum disorders. The term 'autism spectrum disorders' is defined in section 9 of the Teacher Education for Autistic Children Act of 2002. Special rules include approval of courses and programs of study by the State, denial of double benefits, and coordination with other education provisions. The new section in the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a tax credit for expenses related to education and training for autism spectrum disorders. Special rules apply, including coordination with other education provisions and a termination clause for taxable years after December 31, 2007. Additionally, technical and clerical amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow individuals to claim a tax credit for education and training expenses related to autism spectrum disorders. Special rules and coordination with other education provisions are included, with a termination clause for taxable years after December 31, 2007. Technical and clerical amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The amendments allow for a tax credit for education and training expenses related to autism spectrum disorders, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Additionally, a report on autism early intervention activities is required. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to require local educational agencies to report on autism early intervention activities, including referral of students with autism symptoms for diagnosis and providing appropriate training. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act now mandates local educational agencies to report on autism early intervention activities and provide training to personnel and schools for carrying out these activities. The Secretary of Education will offer technical assistance to help agencies comply with reporting requirements. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates reporting on autism early intervention activities and providing training. SEC. 6 establishes a Task Force on Autism Spectrum Disorders. The Secretary of Education will establish a Task Force on Autism Spectrum Disorders to review and improve standards for special education for children with autism. The Task Force will also evaluate the effectiveness of existing educational models and programs for training teachers in this area. The Task Force on Autism Spectrum Disorders will be appointed by the Secretary of Education to review and enhance special education standards for children with autism. Members will include representatives from national autism organizations, individuals with autism spectrum disorder or their parents, and other relevant experts. The Task Force on Autism Spectrum Disorders will have members from academia, Department of Education, and Department of Health and Human Services. Members will be compensated at the maximum rate of basic pay for GS-14 for their duties. The Task Force on Autism Spectrum Disorders members are prohibited from receiving additional compensation as federal employees. They will receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Task Force is required to submit a report annually. The Task Force on Autism Spectrum Disorders must submit an annual report to the Secretary of Education containing review results, evaluations, and recommendations. $500,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2003-2007 to carry out this section, with funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 7. STUDY AND REPORT ON FEDERAL VOCATIONAL TRAINING PROGRAMS. The Secretaries of Education and Labor will conduct a study on the effectiveness of Federal vocational training programs for individuals with autism spectrum disorders. A report with study results and recommendations to improve program effectiveness will be submitted to Congress within 18 months. The Secretaries of Education and Labor will conduct a study on Federal vocational training programs for individuals with autism spectrum disorders to monitor effectiveness. SEC. 8. STATE AUTISM OMBUDSMAN OFFICES. The Secretary of Education provides grants to States that establish and operate a State autism ombudsman office. The office must be led by an individual approved by national non-profit organizations dedicated to addressing the needs of individuals with autism spectrum disorders or their families. A State autism ombudsman office serves individuals with autism spectrum disorders and their families as a resource for legal, educational, and family support systems issues. This includes advising on the individualized education program process, interpreting school communications for children with autistic behavior, proposing alternatives to IEP team suggestions, and mediating between families and school officials. A State autism ombudsman office, established to assist individuals with autism spectrum disorders and their families, must coordinate with various state entities and operate independently of educational agencies. $8,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2003 through 2007 for this purpose. The term "autism spectrum disorders" refers to a group of neurological disabilities characterized by social interaction and communication difficulties, as well as repetitive behaviors. It includes autistic disorder, Asperger's disorder, and pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified.
